resource.name: Current Employee Salaries
resource.description: This dataset contains current active employee data from the most recent semimonthly pay cycle. Information includes employee salary information and department.
columns_description: The current annual salary the employee receives.
Name of the department the employee works for.
Employee last name.
Employee middle initial. This value may be blank if the employee does not have a middle name.
Employee full name.
The employee’s position title.
Employee first name.
Employee name suffix. This value is blank if the employee does not have a name suffix.

resource.name: Greensboro City Council Emails - most recent 12 months, beginning January 1, 2017
resource.description: Emails sent to and from Greensboro City Council Members' City of Greensboro email addresses (most recent 12 months, beginning January 1, 2017). Hover your mouse cursor over the table cells to expand a content box. A full view of the email content can also be displayed in a window at the bottom of the screen, by clicking on a number in the numerical column on the far left of the table. A Public Records Request will need to be submitted to obtain documents referenced as an attachment. To access the City of Greensboro Public Records page, click on the following link: http://www.greensboro-nc.gov/index.aspx?page=3765
columns_description: Formatted body of the email. If the sent email is structured with html, the email displays here formatted as such. Hover over the table cells to read the content. You can also click on the number on the most left-hand column of the dataset to access a single email view of the data.
Date and time the email was sent.
The Councilperson the email was forwarded from.

Body of the email in block text. Hover over the table cells to read the content. You can also click on the number on the most left-hand column of the dataset to access a single email view of the data.
Subject line of the email.

resource.name: Fire Incidents July 1, 2010 - Present
resource.description: Greensboro Fire Incidents
columns_description: NFIRS Code - The heat source that ignited the Item First Ignited to cause the fire.
NFIRS Code - where the fire originated.
Total number of fire service units / apparatus assigned to the incident.
An estimate of property dollar loss due to fire.
An abbreviation of the type of event fire units were dispatched to and does not indicate what was actually found on arrival.
Defines a small geographical area where the station response order is generally the same. Used for reporting purposes.
Represents the geographical area defined as a fire station's first due area. This does not define the station that truly responded to the incident.
The date and time the last fire department unit cleared the incident.
The date and time the fire department indicated the incident could be mitigated with resources assigned to the event.
The date and time the fire department was notified of the incident.
Time in hh:mm:ss representing the amount of time from receipt of the 911 call into the 911 center to the alerting of the fire department for a response.
The method used to extinguish the fire. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.
An estimate of property and content dollar loss due to fire.
Time in hh:mm:ss representing the amount of time from fire department notification until the fire department arrival at the incident address.

National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) exposure number. Zero (0) is the main incident and each number thereafter represents a fire exposure, like a separate building or vehicle as a result of the original fire.
Time in hh:mm:ss representing the amount of time from the receipt of the 911 call into the 911 center until the arrival of the fire department at the incident address.
How the fire was extinguished. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.
An estimate of property value, normally obtained by tax records.

The extent of fire spread in terms of how far the flame damage extended. The extent of flame damage is the
area actually burned or charred and does not include the area receiving only heat, smoke, or water damage.
A National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) value to identify the actual use of the property where the incident occurred.
The date and time the 911 center received the event by by 911 call or radio.
An estimate of content value, normally obtained by tax records and is normally a percentage of property value.
An estimate of property content dollar loss due to fire.
Represents a geographical area for Greensboro Fire Department.
Calendar Year

A civilian fire fatality is a person who is killed as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire
Fiscal Year defined as 07/01/#### to 06/30/####
Defines the shift working at the time of the incident. Greensboro Fire works 24/48 and the shifts are defined as A, B or C

A civilian injury is a person who is injured as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire
Was the building occupied at the time of ignition. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.

A fire service injury is a fire service person who is injured as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire

A fire service fatality is a fire service person who is or killed as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire
Conditional found on arrival of the first arriving  fire department apparatus. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.
The total number of staff members assigned to an incident. This does not indicate all staff member were on the scene.

resource.name: Greensboro Part One Crime Per 100,000 1976 - 2016 - Stacked Column Chart
resource.description:
The Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program has been the starting place for law enforcement executives, students of criminal justice, researchers, members of the media, and the public at large seeking information on crime in the nation. Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes. Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes. This dataset contains FBI Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Part I crime data for the last 40 years in Greensboro, North Carolina. The crime rate or index is calculated on a per 100,000 resident basis.
A crime rate describes the number of crimes reported to law enforcement agencies per 100,000 residents. A crime rate is calculated by dividing the number of reported crimes by the total population; the result is multiplied by 100,000. For example, in 2013 there were 496 robberies in Greensboro and the population was 268,176 according to the SBI estimate. This equals a robbery crime rate of 185 per 100,000 general population.
496/268,176 = 0.00184953165085615 x 100,000 = 184.95
columns_description: In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, property crime includes the offenses of burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson.  The object of the theft-type offenses is the taking of money or property, but there is no force or threat of force against the victims.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines larceny-theft as the unlawful taking, carrying, leading, or riding away of property from the possession or constructive possession of another.  Examples are thefts of bicycles, motor vehicle parts and accessories, shoplifting, pocket-picking, or the stealing of any property or article that is not taken by force and violence or by fraud. Attempted larcenies are included. Embezzlement, confidence games, forgery, check fraud, etc., are excluded.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines burglary as the unlawful entry of a structure to commit a felony or theft. To classify an offense as a burglary, the use of force to gain entry need not have occurred.  The UCR Program has three sub-classifications for burglary: forcible entry, unlawful entry where no force is used, and attempted forcible entry. The UCR definition of “structure” includes apartment, barn, 
house trailer or houseboat when used as a permanent dwelling, office, railroad car (but not automobile), stable, and vessel (i.e., ship).

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines robbery as the taking or attempting to take anything of value from the care, custody, or control of a person or persons by force or threat of force or violence and/or by putting the victim in fear.  These instances include Robbery of Individual as well as Commercial Robbery.

Forcible rape, as defined in the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, is the carnal knowledge of a person forcibly and against their will.  Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  Attempts or assaults to commit rape by force or threat of force are also included; however, statutory rape (without force) and other sex offenses are excluded.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines murder as the willful killing of one human being by another. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  The UCR Program does not include the following situations in this offense classification: deaths caused by negligence, suicide, or accident; justifiable homicides; and attempts to murder or assaults to murder, which are scored as aggravated assaults.

Population figures for 2014 and 2015 are from the City's Planning Department.  Previously North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation estimates were used to determine population figure, with the exception of years where US Census values were known.

Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines aggravated assault as an unlawful attack by one person upon another for the purpose of inflicting severe or aggravated bodily injury. The UCR Program further specifies that this type of assault is usually accompanied by the use of a weapon or by other means likely to produce death or great bodily harm. Attempted aggravated assault that involves the display of—or threat to use—a gun, knife, or other weapon is included in this crime category because serious personal injury would likely result if the assault were completed. Shooting into Occupied Dwelling is included. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.
Represents a calendar year from January 1st through December 31st.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, motor vehicle theft is defined as the theft or attempted theft of a motor vehicle. In the UCR Program, a motor vehicle is a self-propelled vehicle that runs on land surfaces and not on rails.  Examples of motor vehicles include sport utility vehicles, automobiles, trucks, buses, motorcycles, motor scooters, all-terrain vehicles, and snowmobiles.  Motor vehicle theft does not include farm equipment, bulldozers, airplanes, construction equipment, or watercraft such as motorboats, sailboats, houseboats, or jet skis.  The taking of a motor vehicle for temporary use by persons having lawful access is excluded from this definition.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, violent crime is composed of four offenses: murder, forcible rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. Violent crimes are defined in the UCR Program as those offenses, which involve force or threat of force.

resource.name: Uncashed Checks
resource.description: This dataset includes records of all Accounts Payable (AP) checks issued by the City of Greensboro that have not yet been cashed or deposited by the payee, or have otherwise not cleared the City’s bank account. This dataset does not include employee payroll checks, utility refunds, or checks issued by the Greensboro Coliseum.
columns_description: Describes the status of the check transaction (OUTSTAND= outstanding)

Examples of motor vehicles include sport utility vehicles, automobiles, trucks, buses, motorcycles, motor scooters, all-terrain vehicles, and snowmobiles.  Motor vehicle theft does not include farm equipment, bulldozers, airplanes, construction equipment, or watercraft such as motorboats, sailboats, houseboats, or jet skis.  The taking of a motor vehicle for temporary use by persons having lawful access is excluded from this definition.
Represents a calendar year from January 1st through December 31st.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, violent crime is composed of four offenses: murder, forcible rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. Violent crimes are defined in the UCR Program as those offenses, which involve force or threat of force.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, property crime includes the offenses of burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson.  The object of the theft-type offenses is the taking of money or property, but there is no force or threat of force against the victims.

Forcible rape, as defined in the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, is the carnal knowledge of a person forcibly and against their will.  Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  Attempts or assaults to commit rape by force or threat of force are also included; however, statutory rape (without force) and other sex offenses are excluded.

Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.

resource.name: Greensboro Violent Crime Numbers 1975 - 2016 - Line Chart
resource.description: The Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program has been the starting place for law enforcement executives, students of criminal justice, researchers, members of the media, and the public at large seeking information on crime in the nation.  Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.  This dataset contains FBI Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Part I crime data for the last 40 years in Greensboro, North Carolina.
columns_description: The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines aggravated assault as an unlawful attack by one person upon another for the purpose of inflicting severe or aggravated bodily injury. The UCR Program further specifies that this type of assault is usually accompanied by the use of a weapon or by other means likely to produce death or great bodily harm. Attempted aggravated assault that involves the display of—or threat to use—a gun, knife, or other weapon is included in this crime category because serious personal injury would likely result if the assault were completed. Shooting into Occupied Dwelling is included. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines murder as the willful killing of one human being by another. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  The UCR Program does not include the following situations in this offense classification: deaths caused by negligence, suicide, or accident; justifiable homicides; and attempts to murder or assaults to murder, which are scored as aggravated assaults.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, property crime includes the offenses of burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson.  The object of the theft-type offenses is the taking of money or property, but there is no force or threat of force against the victims.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, violent crime is composed of four offenses: murder, forcible rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. Violent crimes are defined in the UCR Program as those offenses, which involve force or threat of force.
Represents a calendar year from January 1st through December 31st.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, motor vehicle theft is defined as the theft or attempted theft of a motor vehicle. In the UCR Program, a motor vehicle is a self-propelled vehicle that runs on land surfaces and not on rails.  Examples of motor vehicles include sport utility vehicles, automobiles, trucks, buses, motorcycles, motor scooters, all-terrain vehicles, and snowmobiles.  Motor vehicle theft does not include farm equipment, bulldozers, airplanes, construction equipment, or watercraft such as motorboats, sailboats, houseboats, or jet skis.  The taking of a motor vehicle for temporary use by persons having lawful access is excluded from this definition.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines larceny-theft as the unlawful taking, carrying, leading, or riding away of property from the possession or constructive possession of another.  Examples are thefts of bicycles, motor vehicle parts and accessories, shoplifting, pocket-picking, or the stealing of any property or article that is not taken by force and violence or by fraud. Attempted larcenies are included. Embezzlement, confidence games, forgery, check fraud, etc., are excluded.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines burglary as the unlawful entry of a structure to commit a felony or theft. To classify an offense as a burglary, the use of force to gain entry need not have occurred.  The UCR Program has three sub-classifications for burglary: forcible entry, unlawful entry where no force is used, and attempted forcible entry. The UCR definition of “structure” includes apartment, barn, 
house trailer or houseboat when used as a permanent dwelling, office, railroad car (but not automobile), stable, and vessel (i.e., ship).

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines robbery as the taking or attempting to take anything of value from the care, custody, or control of a person or persons by force or threat of force or violence and/or by putting the victim in fear.  These instances include Robbery of Individual as well as Commercial Robbery.

Forcible rape, as defined in the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, is the carnal knowledge of a person forcibly and against their will.  Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  Attempts or assaults to commit rape by force or threat of force are also included; however, statutory rape (without force) and other sex offenses are excluded.

Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.

Population figures for 2014 and 2015 are from the City's Planning Department.  Previously North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation estimates were used to determine population figure, with the exception of years where US Census values were known.

resource.name: 2017 YTD View
resource.description: Greensboro Fire Incidents
columns_description: Time in hh:mm:ss representing the amount of time from the receipt of the 911 call into the 911 center until the arrival of the fire department at the incident address.
An estimate of property value, normally obtained by tax records.
The date and time the fire department indicated the incident could be mitigated with resources assigned to the event.
The date and time the 911 center received the event by by 911 call or radio.
Represents the geographical area defined as a fire station's first due area. This does not define the station that truly responded to the incident.
Calendar Year
Represents a geographical area for Greensboro Fire Department.
Fiscal Year defined as 07/01/#### to 06/30/####
The date and time the fire department was notified of the incident.

National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) exposure number. Zero (0) is the main incident and each number thereafter represents a fire exposure, like a separate building or vehicle as a result of the original fire.

A civilian injury is a person who is injured as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire
Was the building occupied at the time of ignition. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.

The extent of fire spread in terms of how far the flame damage extended. The extent of flame damage is the
area actually burned or charred and does not include the area receiving only heat, smoke, or water damage.
Time in hh:mm:ss representing the amount of time from fire department notification until the fire department arrival at the incident address.
Time in hh:mm:ss representing the amount of time from receipt of the 911 call into the 911 center to the alerting of the fire department for a response.
NFIRS Code - The heat source that ignited the Item First Ignited to cause the fire.
Conditional found on arrival of the first arriving  fire department apparatus. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.
An estimate of content value, normally obtained by tax records and is normally a percentage of property value.
NFIRS Code - where the fire originated.
The method used to extinguish the fire. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.
Total number of fire service units / apparatus assigned to the incident.
How the fire was extinguished. This field is required for all structure fires from 01/01/2014 forward.
The total number of staff members assigned to an incident. This does not indicate all staff member were on the scene.

A fire service fatality is a fire service person who is or killed as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire

A civilian fire fatality is a person who is killed as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire

A fire service injury is a fire service person who is injured as a result of a fire, including injuries or deaths
from natural or accidental causes sustained while involved in the activities of fire control, attempting
rescue, or escaping from the dangers of the fire
An estimate of property and content dollar loss due to fire.
An estimate of property content dollar loss due to fire.
An estimate of property dollar loss due to fire.
A National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) value to identify the actual use of the property where the incident occurred.
An abbreviation of the type of event fire units were dispatched to and does not indicate what was actually found on arrival.
Defines a small geographical area where the station response order is generally the same. Used for reporting purposes.
Defines the shift working at the time of the incident. Greensboro Fire works 24/48 and the shifts are defined as A, B or C
The date and time the last fire department unit cleared the incident.

resource.name: Part I Crime Summary 1975 - 2016
resource.description: The Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program has been the starting place for law enforcement executives, students of criminal justice, researchers, members of the media, and the public at large seeking information on crime in the nation.  Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.  This dataset contains FBI Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Part I crime data for the last 40 years in Greensboro, North Carolina.
columns_description: Represents a calendar year from January 1st through December 31st.

Population figures for 2014 and 2015 are from the City's Planning Department.  Previously North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation estimates were used to determine population figure, with the exception of years where US Census values were known.

Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, violent crime is composed of four offenses: murder, forcible rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. Violent crimes are defined in the UCR Program as those offenses, which involve force or threat of force.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, property crime includes the offenses of burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson.  The object of the theft-type offenses is the taking of money or property, but there is no force or threat of force against the victims.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines murder as the willful killing of one human being by another. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  The UCR Program does not include the following situations in this offense classification: deaths caused by negligence, suicide, or accident; justifiable homicides; and attempts to murder or assaults to murder, which are scored as aggravated assaults.

Forcible rape, as defined in the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, is the carnal knowledge of a person forcibly and against their will.  Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  Attempts or assaults to commit rape by force or threat of force are also included; however, statutory rape (without force) and other sex offenses are excluded.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines robbery as the taking or attempting to take anything of value from the care, custody, or control of a person or persons by force or threat of force or violence and/or by putting the victim in fear.  These instances include Robbery of Individual as well as Commercial Robbery.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines aggravated assault as an unlawful attack by one person upon another for the purpose of inflicting severe or aggravated bodily injury. The UCR Program further specifies that this type of assault is usually accompanied by the use of a weapon or by other means likely to produce death or great bodily harm. Attempted aggravated assault that involves the display of—or threat to use—a gun, knife, or other weapon is included in this crime category because serious personal injury would likely result if the assault were completed. Shooting into Occupied Dwelling is included. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines burglary as the unlawful entry of a structure to commit a felony or theft. To classify an offense as a burglary, the use of force to gain entry need not have occurred.  The UCR Program has three sub-classifications for burglary: forcible entry, unlawful entry where no force is used, and attempted forcible entry. The UCR definition of “structure” includes apartment, barn, 
house trailer or houseboat when used as a permanent dwelling, office, railroad car (but not automobile), stable, and vessel (i.e., ship).

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines larceny-theft as the unlawful taking, carrying, leading, or riding away of property from the possession or constructive possession of another.  Examples are thefts of bicycles, motor vehicle parts and accessories, shoplifting, pocket-picking, or the stealing of any property or article that is not taken by force and violence or by fraud. Attempted larcenies are included. Embezzlement, confidence games, forgery, check fraud, etc., are excluded.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, motor vehicle theft is defined as the theft or attempted theft of a motor vehicle. In the UCR Program, a motor vehicle is a self-propelled vehicle that runs on land surfaces and not on rails.  Examples of motor vehicles include sport utility vehicles, automobiles, trucks, buses, motorcycles, motor scooters, all-terrain vehicles, and snowmobiles.  Motor vehicle theft does not include farm equipment, bulldozers, airplanes, construction equipment, or watercraft such as motorboats, sailboats, houseboats, or jet skis.  The taking of a motor vehicle for temporary use by persons having lawful access is excluded from this definition.

resource.name: Part I Crime Indexed Per 100,000 Residents 1975 - 2016
resource.description:
The Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program has been the starting place for law enforcement executives, students of criminal justice, researchers, members of the media, and the public at large seeking information on crime in the nation.  Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.  This dataset contains FBI Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Part I crime data for the last 40 years in Greensboro, North Carolina.  The crime rate or index is calculated on a per 100,000 resident basis.
A crime rate describes the number of crimes reported to law enforcement agencies per 100,000 residents.  A crime rate is calculated by dividing the number of reported crimes by the total population; the result is multiplied by 100,000.  For example, in 2013 there were 496 robberies in Greensboro and the population was 268,176 according to the SBI estimate. This equals a robbery crime rate of 185 per 100,000 general population.
496/268,176 = 0.00184953165085615 x 100,000 = 184.95
columns_description: Represents a calendar year from January 1st through December 31st.

Population figures for 2014 and 2015 are from the City's Planning Department.  Previously North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation estimates were used to determine population figure, with the exception of years where US Census values were known.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines murder as the willful killing of one human being by another. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  The UCR Program does not include the following situations in this offense classification: deaths caused by negligence, suicide, or accident; justifiable homicides; and attempts to murder or assaults to murder, which are scored as aggravated assaults.

Forcible rape, as defined in the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, is the carnal knowledge of a person forcibly and against their will.  Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  Attempts or assaults to commit rape by force or threat of force are also included; however, statutory rape (without force) and other sex offenses are excluded.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines robbery as the taking or attempting to take anything of value from the care, custody, or control of a person or persons by force or threat of force or violence and/or by putting the victim in fear.  These instances include Robbery of Individual as well as Commercial Robbery.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines aggravated assault as an unlawful attack by one person upon another for the purpose of inflicting severe or aggravated bodily injury. The UCR Program further specifies that this type of assault is usually accompanied by the use of a weapon or by other means likely to produce death or great bodily harm. Attempted aggravated assault that involves the display of—or threat to use—a gun, knife, or other weapon is included in this crime category because serious personal injury would likely result if the assault were completed. Shooting into Occupied Dwelling is included. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines burglary as the unlawful entry of a structure to commit a felony or theft. To classify an offense as a burglary, the use of force to gain entry need not have occurred.  The UCR Program has three sub-classifications for burglary: forcible entry, unlawful entry where no force is used, and attempted forcible entry. The UCR definition of “structure” includes apartment, barn, 
house trailer or houseboat when used as a permanent dwelling, office, railroad car (but not automobile), stable, and vessel (i.e., ship).

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines larceny-theft as the unlawful taking, carrying, leading, or riding away of property from the possession or constructive possession of another.  Examples are thefts of bicycles, motor vehicle parts and accessories, shoplifting, pocket-picking, or the stealing of any property or article that is not taken by force and violence or by fraud. Attempted larcenies are included. Embezzlement, confidence games, forgery, check fraud, etc., are excluded.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, motor vehicle theft is defined as the theft or attempted theft of a motor vehicle. In the UCR Program, a motor vehicle is a self-propelled vehicle that runs on land surfaces and not on rails.  Examples of motor vehicles include sport utility vehicles, automobiles, trucks, buses, motorcycles, motor scooters, all-terrain vehicles, and snowmobiles.  Motor vehicle theft does not include farm equipment, bulldozers, airplanes, construction equipment, or watercraft such as motorboats, sailboats, houseboats, or jet skis.  The taking of a motor vehicle for temporary use by persons having lawful access is excluded from this definition.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, property crime includes the offenses of burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson.  The object of the theft-type offenses is the taking of money or property, but there is no force or threat of force against the victims.

Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.

resource.name: Invoice Spend for Purchase Orders Only by Fiscal Year 2011/2012 - Present
resource.description: This dataset represents all purchase orders that were paid in the from July 1, 2011 to present. It does not include other payment types. Purchase orders may be repeated in the table, which indicates that multiple invoices were paid for the respective purchase order.
columns_description: The amount in U.S. dollars on the invoice for the PO.
The City's 'fiscal' year runs from July 1 to June 30 each year.
Category of Purchase Order. For example, the purchase order may be created for a construction contract, a professional service, or a standard purchase.

resource.description: This dataset includes records of all Accounts Payable (AP) checks issued by the City of Greensboro that have not yet been cashed or deposited by the payee, or have otherwise not cleared the City’s bank account. This dataset does not include employee payroll checks, utility refunds, or checks issued by the Greensboro Coliseum.

resource.name: Greensboro Indexed Property Crime Per 100,000 1976 - 2016 - Line Chart
resource.description:
The Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program has been the starting place for law enforcement executives, students of criminal justice, researchers, members of the media, and the public at large seeking information on crime in the nation. Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes. Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes. This dataset contains FBI Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Part I crime data for the last 40 years in Greensboro, North Carolina. The crime rate or index is calculated on a per 100,000 resident basis.
A crime rate describes the number of crimes reported to law enforcement agencies per 100,000 residents. A crime rate is calculated by dividing the number of reported crimes by the total population; the result is multiplied by 100,000. For example, in 2013 there were 496 robberies in Greensboro and the population was 268,176 according to the SBI estimate. This equals a robbery crime rate of 185 per 100,000 general population.
496/268,176 = 0.00184953165085615 x 100,000 = 184.95
columns_description: Part I categorizes incidents in two categories: violent and property crimes.  Aggravated assault, forcible rape, murder, and robbery are classified as violent crime, while burglary, larceny-theft, and motor vehicle theft are classified as property crimes.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, property crime includes the offenses of burglary, larceny-theft, motor vehicle theft, and arson.  The object of the theft-type offenses is the taking of money or property, but there is no force or threat of force against the victims.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, motor vehicle theft is defined as the theft or attempted theft of a motor vehicle. In the UCR Program, a motor vehicle is a self-propelled vehicle that runs on land surfaces and not on rails.  Examples of motor vehicles include sport utility vehicles, automobiles, trucks, buses, motorcycles, motor scooters, all-terrain vehicles, and snowmobiles.  Motor vehicle theft does not include farm equipment, bulldozers, airplanes, construction equipment, or watercraft such as motorboats, sailboats, houseboats, or jet skis.  The taking of a motor vehicle for temporary use by persons having lawful access is excluded from this definition.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines larceny-theft as the unlawful taking, carrying, leading, or riding away of property from the possession or constructive possession of another.  Examples are thefts of bicycles, motor vehicle parts and accessories, shoplifting, pocket-picking, or the stealing of any property or article that is not taken by force and violence or by fraud. Attempted larcenies are included. Embezzlement, confidence games, forgery, check fraud, etc., are excluded.

In the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, violent crime is composed of four offenses: murder, forcible rape, robbery, and aggravated assault. Violent crimes are defined in the UCR Program as those offenses, which involve force or threat of force.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines aggravated assault as an unlawful attack by one person upon another for the purpose of inflicting severe or aggravated bodily injury. The UCR Program further specifies that this type of assault is usually accompanied by the use of a weapon or by other means likely to produce death or great bodily harm. Attempted aggravated assault that involves the display of—or threat to use—a gun, knife, or other weapon is included in this crime category because serious personal injury would likely result if the assault were completed. Shooting into Occupied Dwelling is included. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines robbery as the taking or attempting to take anything of value from the care, custody, or control of a person or persons by force or threat of force or violence and/or by putting the victim in fear.  These instances include Robbery of Individual as well as Commercial Robbery.
Represents a calendar year from January 1st through December 31st.

Forcible rape, as defined in the FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program, is the carnal knowledge of a person forcibly and against their will.  Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  Attempts or assaults to commit rape by force or threat of force are also included; however, statutory rape (without force) and other sex offenses are excluded.

Population figures for 2014 and 2015 are from the City's Planning Department.  Previously North Carolina State Bureau of Investigation estimates were used to determine population figure, with the exception of years where US Census values were known.

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines burglary as the unlawful entry of a structure to commit a felony or theft. To classify an offense as a burglary, the use of force to gain entry need not have occurred.  The UCR Program has three sub-classifications for burglary: forcible entry, unlawful entry where no force is used, and attempted forcible entry. The UCR definition of “structure” includes apartment, barn, 
house trailer or houseboat when used as a permanent dwelling, office, railroad car (but not automobile), stable, and vessel (i.e., ship).

The FBI’s Uniform Crime Reporting (UCR) Program defines murder as the willful killing of one human being by another. Violent crime in UCR Reports counts the number of victims, not incidents.  The UCR Program does not include the following situations in this offense classification: deaths caused by negligence, suicide, or accident; justifiable homicides; and attempts to murder or assaults to murder, which are scored as aggravated assaults.
